title: Formation of Metal Atom Chains at the Edges of Graphene Nanoribbons Supported by Graphene
content: Graphene, essential for future integrated circuits, faces challenges due to its lack of a bandgap [1]. Graphene nanoribbons (GNRs), as confined quasi-one-dimensional structures, offer tunable bandgaps [1]. Their electronic properties are influenced by their width, chirality, and edge structure. Zigzag edges exhibit metallic behavior with magnetic ordering, while armchair edges have a width-dependent bandgap [2]. Doping and edge modifications enhance the functionality of GNRs. Metal atoms on GNR edges can also modulate their electronic and magnetic properties [2]. While single metal atoms have been observed on graphene edges, the formation of longer chains remains elusive [2]. Since metal atoms attached to the edges of GNRs modify their electronic and catalytic properties, we experimentally create linear chains of indium (In) atoms along GNR edges.
